He denies any recent trauma, fever, chills, or significant weight loss. He has not experienced any skin rashes or joint swelling. He did have an episode of increased urinary urgency about a month ago that lasted a few days and resolved spontaneously, without dysuria.

Several prominent, slightly engorged blood vessels were noted on the surface of the median and lateral prostatic lobes near the bladder neck.
Flexible_Cystoscopy_Report.Conclusion: Findings consistent with benign prostatic enlargement causing bladder outlet effects. Prominent prostatic vessels are a likely source of haematuria. No evidence of bladder malignancy.

CT_Urogram_with_intravenous_contrast_nep.Upper_Tracts: Normal appearance of kidneys and ureters bilaterally. No filling defects, masses, calculi, or hydronephrosis. Symmetrical and prompt excretion of contrast.

No enlarged pelvic or retroperitoneal lymph nodes.
CT_Urogram_with_intravenous_contrast_nep.Other_Abdominal_Pelvic_Organs: Liver, spleen, pancreas, adrenal glands, and visualized bowel loops are unremarkable. No distant metastatic disease identified.

Flexible_Cystoscopy_and_Transurethral_Re.Findings: Cystoscopy revealed a solitary, approximately 1.5 cm, solid-appearing (sessile) papillary tumour on the right lateral wall of the bladder. The surrounding mucosa appeared normal. Ureteric orifices visualized and appeared normal. TURBT was performed, resecting the tumour down to deep muscle.
Flexible_Cystoscopy_and_Transurethral_Re.Histopathology_Report: Specimen A (Tumour Chips): High-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma, invading the lamina propria (pT1). Muscularis propria (detrusor muscle) is present in the specimen and is NOT involved by tumour. Specimen B (Tumour Base): Muscularis propria present, no tumour seen.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Bladder tumour (High-grade pT1 papillary urothelial carcinoma)

She denies any significant pain during urination but feels a vague, mild discomfort in her lower abdomen, which she mentions has happened before around the time of her menses, although she is 'a bit irregular' and not entirely sure when her last period was or when the next is due. She has not experienced any fevers or chills. She is otherwise feeling well.
Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: No history of kidney disease, kidney stones, or recurrent urinary tract infections. Appendectomy 10 years ago. No known bleeding disorders. Takes oral contraceptive pill fairly regularly but admits to occasionally missing a pill. Last cervical smear (2 years ago) was normal.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Non-smoker. Drinks socially (2-3 glasses of wine on weekends). Works part-time as a barista while studying. Denies illicit drug use. Reports being in a stable monogamous relationship.
Patient_Actor.Medications: Combined oral contraceptive pill (Microgynon 30). Takes ibuprofen occasionally for menstrual cramps or headaches.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies frank dysuria, increased urinary frequency, or true urgency. Denies foul-smelling urine. No flank pain, nausea, or vomiting. No recent trauma or strenuous exercise. No skin rashes, joint pains, or oral ulcers. No significant unexplained weight loss. No history of easy bruising or prolonged bleeding. Denies any new vaginal discharge, itching, or odor. She cannot recall the exact date of her last menstrual period but thinks it might have been 'around 3-4 weeks ago'.

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Alert, oriented, and appears well. Calm and cooperative. Not in acute distress.

Abdominal_Examination.Inspection: Abdomen flat, previous appendectomy scar in RIF, well-healed. No distension, no visible masses or discoloration.
Abdominal_Examination.Auscultation: Normoactive bowel sounds in all four quadrants.
Abdominal_Examination.Percussion: Non-tender to percussion throughout. No dullness to suggest organomegaly.
Abdominal_Examination.Palpation: Soft. Mild, diffuse suprapubic tenderness elicited on deep palpation, which the patient states is similar to her usual premenstrual discomfort. No guarding or rebound tenderness. Kidneys not palpable. No hepatosplenomegaly.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Cardiovascular_Examination: Regular rate and rhythm. S1 and S2 heart sounds normal. No murmurs, rubs, or gallops.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Respiratory_Examination: Chest clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi. Symmetric chest expansion.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Back_Examination: No costovertebral angle tenderness elicited bilaterally.

Urine_Analysis_Initial_Sample.Collection_Method: Patient-provided mid-stream urine sample in clinic, after brief verbal instruction.

Microscopy.Epithelial_cells: Moderate numbers of squamous epithelial cells

Renal_and_Pelvic_Ultrasound.Reason_for_scan: Investigate haematuria, rule out urolithiasis or structural renal/pelvic pathology.
Renal_and_Pelvic_Ultrasound.Findings: Kidneys are normal in size, position, and echotexture. No evidence of hydronephrosis, calculi, cysts or solid masses. Ureters are not dilated. Bladder is well-distended, with a normal wall thickness and no intraluminal lesions or stones. Uterus and ovaries appear normal, with a physiological corpus luteum seen on the right ovary. No adnexal masses or significant free fluid in the pelvis.

Further_Investigations_and_Follow_up.Patient_Communication: Discussed initial findings with the patient. Explained that while the urine shows blood, other tests are reassuring. Highlighted the presence of squamous epithelial cells and the possibility of menstrual contamination, especially given her uncertain cycle timing. Advised on importance of a carefully collected repeat sample.
Further_Investigations_and_Follow_up.Patient_Instructions: Provided with detailed verbal and written instructions for a clean-catch mid-stream urine (MSU) sample collection, emphasizing perineal cleansing. Advised to provide the sample once she is certain she is not menstruating, or in 5-7 days if no menses occur.

Repeat_Urine_Analysis_MSU.Collection_Context: Patient returned 6 days later, reporting onset of menses 3 days after initial visit, which has now stopped. Sample collected as per MSU instructions.

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Alert, oriented, and cooperative. Appears well-nourished and in no acute distress. Normal body habitus.

Abdominal_Examination.Inspection: Abdomen is flat. Well-healed appendectomy scar in the right lower quadrant. No visible distension, masses, or skin changes.

Abdominal_Examination.Palpation: Soft and non-tender to light palpation. Mild tenderness elicited on deep palpation in the right flank region, without guarding or rebound. No palpable masses. Liver span normal, spleen not palpable. No hepatosplenomegaly.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Cardiovascular_Examination: Regular rate and rhythm. S1 and S2 heart sounds normal. No murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Peripheral pulses present and symmetrical.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Digital_Rectal_Examination: Prostate is moderately enlarged, smooth, firm, non-tender, with a palpable median sulcus. No distinct nodules felt. Stool brown, guaiac negative.

Urine_Cytology.Findings: Atypical urothelial cells present, some with features suspicious for low-grade urothelial neoplasm. Recommend further urological evaluation and imaging.

Renal_and_Bladder_Ultrasound.Findings: Right kidney measures 11.5 cm, left kidney 11.2 cm. Both show normal cortical thickness and echogenicity. Mild right-sided hydronephrosis and proximal hydroureter are noted, extending to the mid-ureter. The distal ureter is obscured by bowel gas. No renal calculi or obvious renal masses identified. Bladder is moderately distended, showing diffuse mild wall thickening (average 5mm). No discrete intraluminal mass clearly visualized, but assessment limited by wall thickening. Post-void residual volume 60 mL.

CT_Urogram.Findings: Multiphase CT urogram demonstrates an irregular, sessile soft tissue mass measuring approximately 2.5 cm x 1.8 cm within the right renal pelvis, showing heterogeneous enhancement in the nephrogenic and excretory phases. This lesion is causing partial obstruction of the right pelvicalyceal system, resulting in mild proximal hydronephrosis and hydroureter down to the level of the iliac vessels. The distal ureter appears unremarkable. The bladder wall appears mildly thickened diffusely, but no discrete enhancing mass or filling defect is seen within the bladder lumen. Left kidney and ureter are unremarkable. Liver, spleen, pancreas, and adrenal glands are normal. Several small (up to 7mm short axis) non-specific retroperitoneal lymph nodes are noted. No evidence of distant metastatic disease in the visualized portions of the abdomen and pelvis.

Cystoscopy_and_Right_Ureteroscopy.Cystoscopy_Findings: The urethra was normal. Bladder mucosa showed mild generalized trabeculation consistent with age and some chronic outflow changes; however, no papillary tumors, carcinoma in situ, or other suspicious lesions were identified within the bladder. Both ureteric orifices were identified and appeared normal.
Cystoscopy_and_Right_Ureteroscopy.Right_Ureteroscopy_Findings: Flexible ureteroscopy was performed up the right ureter. An irregular, sessile, somewhat friable tumor was visualized occupying a significant portion of the right renal pelvis, extending slightly into the superior calyx. The tumor measured approximately 2-3 cm in its largest dimensions. Multiple biopsies were taken from the lesion. The remainder of the ureter appeared normal.

Right_Renal_Pelvis_Biopsy.Findings: Fragments of urothelial tissue showing features of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma. Lamina propria invasion is identified. Muscularis propria not definitively present in biopsy fragments for assessment of depth of invasion.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: High-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma of the right renal pelvis (Upper Tract Urothelial Carcinoma - UTUC)

Renal_Bladder_Ultrasound.Findings: Kidneys are normal in size, position, and echotexture. No hydronephrosis, calculi, or solid masses identified bilaterally. Bladder is well-distended, with a smooth wall. No intraluminal masses or stones. Post-void residual volume is 40 mL. Prostate gland is moderately enlarged, estimated volume 45cc, with a heterogeneous echotexture but no clearly defined focal lesion seen via transabdominal approach.

CT_Urography.Findings: Excretory phase images demonstrate prompt bilateral contrast excretion with normal appearance of the pelvicalyceal systems and ureters; no filling defects or strictures. Bladder appears normal in contour and wall thickness, with no definite intraluminal mass. Prostate gland is enlarged, measuring approximately 5.0 x 4.2 x 3.8 cm, and shows heterogeneous enhancement. Several borderline prominent pelvic lymph nodes (up to 9mm in short axis diameter) are noted in the internal iliac and obturator regions bilaterally, of uncertain significance, potentially reactive. Mild degenerative changes in the lumbar spine. No suspicious osseous lesions identified in the visualized skeleton.

Flexible_Cystoscopy.Findings: Urethra negotiated without difficulty. Prostatic urethra shows evidence of trilobar prostatic enlargement with some irregularity of the mucosa, particularly on the right lateral lobe, but no distinct exophytic lesion or active bleeding source. Bladder neck is somewhat elevated. Bladder mucosa appears entirely normal throughout. No tumours, stones, or areas of significant inflammation noted. Both ureteric orifices visualized and appear normal, with clear efflux of urine from both sides.

Transrectal_Ultrasound_TRUS_and_Prostate.Findings: TRUS imaging reveals a 1.5 cm hypoechoic area in the right peripheral zone of the prostate, extending towards the mid-gland. Prostate volume estimated at 52cc. Systematic 12-core biopsies were taken from bilateral peripheral zones, transition zones, and two additional targeted biopsies from the hypoechoic lesion. Histopathology: Biopsies from the right peripheral zone hypoechoic lesion and adjacent cores confirm adenocarcinoma, Gleason Score 3+4=7 (Grade Group 2). Approximately 40% of cores positive on the right side. Left-sided biopsies show benign prostatic hyperplasia with chronic inflammation. No extraprostatic extension identified in biopsy material.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Prostate Cancer (Adenocarcinoma, Gleason Score 3+4=7, Grade Group 2)

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents to the emergency department reporting two episodes of dark red urine noticed today. He states that two days ago, he had a fall from his mountain bike, landing on his right side. He describes it as 'not a major crash,' feeling mostly 'winded' and sore afterwards, and was able to continue his ride. He did not seek medical attention at the time. The flank soreness has persisted as a dull ache, rated 3/10, predominantly on the right. He denies any previous episodes of haematuria or known kidney problems. He took two tablets of ibuprofen yesterday for generalized muscle soreness from the fall.
Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: No chronic illnesses. No history of kidney stones, urinary tract infections, bleeding disorders, or previous abdominal/pelvic surgery. Vaccinations up to date.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Works as a software developer. Active, enjoys mountain biking on weekends. Non-smoker. Drinks 2-3 beers socially on weekends. Denies illicit drug use.
Patient_Actor.Medications: Ibuprofen 400mg, one dose yesterday. No regular medications. No known drug allergies.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies fever, chills, night sweats. Denies dysuria, urinary frequency, or urgency. Denies penile discharge or scrotal pain. No history of easy bruising or prolonged bleeding. Denies nausea, vomiting, or changes in bowel habits. No chest pain, palpitations, or shortness of breath. No headache, dizziness, or loss of consciousness associated with the fall. No visible injuries elsewhere noted by the patient immediately after the fall.

Abdominal_Examination.Percussion: Non-tender to percussion generally. Mild tenderness elicited over the right flank.
Abdominal_Examination.Palpation: Abdomen is soft. Mild tenderness to palpation in the right flank and right upper quadrant. No guarding, rigidity, or rebound tenderness. Liver and spleen not palpable. No palpable masses.

Back_Examination.Inspection: Normal spinal alignment. Faint ecchymosis over right flank as noted above.
Back_Examination.Palpation: Mild right costovertebral angle (CVA) tenderness. No spinal tenderness.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Cardiovascular_Examination: Regular rate and rhythm. S1, S2 normal. No murmurs, rubs, or gallops.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Respiratory_Examination: Chest clear to auscultation bilaterally. Symmetric chest expansion. No crepitus or tenderness on chest wall palpation.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Neurological_Examination: Glasgow Coma Scale 15/15. Cranial nerves II-XII intact. Motor strength 5/5 in all limbs. Sensation intact. Reflexes normal and symmetric. No focal neurological deficits.

Blood_Tests.Group_and_Save: Blood Group A Positive, Antibody Screen Negative

ECG.Findings: Sinus rhythm, rate 88 bpm. Normal axis. No ST segment elevation or depression. No Q waves. PR and QTc intervals within normal limits.

Chest_X_ray_AP_view.Findings: Lungs are clear. No pneumothorax or hemothorax. No acute rib fractures identified. Cardiomediastinal silhouette is within normal limits.

Focused_Assessment_with_Sonography_for_T.Findings: Equivocal finding of a very small sliver of hypoechoic fluid in the right perinephric space. No free fluid identified in Morrison's pouch, splenorenal recess, or the pelvis. Cardiac views normal.

CT_Abdomen_Pelvis_with_IV_Contrast_Traum.Findings: Right kidney: A 2.5 cm laceration is identified in the midpole, consistent with an AAST Grade II renal injury. This does not appear to extend into the collecting system on arterial or portal venous phases. A small right perinephric hematoma measuring approximately 3 cm in maximal thickness is present. Delayed phase imaging at 10 minutes shows no definite contrast extravasation from the right renal collecting system. Left kidney is normal. Liver, spleen, pancreas, adrenal glands, and visualized bowel loops are unremarkable. No free intraperitoneal air or significant fluid. Bladder is intact. No pelvic fractures identified. The aorta and IVC are patent.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Trauma: Blunt (Right Renal Laceration - AAST Grade II)

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents to her GP primarily for ongoing management of her chronic low back pain, which she describes as a dull ache, worse with prolonged standing. During the consultation, when specifically asked about urinary or gynaecological issues as part of a routine review, she mentions noticing intermittent, small spots of bright red blood on her underwear over the past 3-4 months. This occurs perhaps once or twice a week, often after she has strained during a bowel movement due to chronic constipation. She is unsure if the blood is related to urination but has not seen it in the toilet bowl or mixed with urine. She also reports a mild, vague sensation of 'irritation' or 'soreness' in the genital area at times, which she has attributed to 'dryness' associated with her age. She denies any recent trauma.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Intermittent bright red blood spotting on underwear
Secondary_Symptoms: Chronic low back pain (presenting complaint focus by patient)

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Hypertension (diagnosed 10 years ago, well-controlled). Osteoarthritis affecting knees and lower back. Menopause aged 52. Three normal vaginal deliveries. No history of kidney stones, urinary tract infections in the last 5 years, or urological cancers. No previous gynaecological surgeries other than tubal ligation.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Retired school teacher. Non-smoker. Drinks one glass of wine on weekends. Lives with her husband. Moderately active, enjoys gardening. Denies illicit drug use.
Patient_Actor.Medications: Amlodipine 5mg daily, Paracetamol 500mg as needed for back pain (takes 2-4 tablets per week). Occasional use of senna for constipation. No anticoagulants or antiplatelet agents. No known drug allergies.

Denies gross haematuria. Denies severe flank pain or abdominal pain. Bowel habits: chronic constipation, otherwise no change. No melena or hematochezia. Denies chest pain or palpitations. Denies skin rashes or joint swelling (other than known osteoarthritis).

Referral_to_Urology_for_Cystoscopy_Consi.Note: Given the visible urethral lesion which is the likely source of bleeding, and normal upper tract imaging, cystoscopy may be deferred if symptoms resolve with local treatment of the caruncle. However, it could be considered if bleeding persists or if there's any diagnostic uncertainty to definitively rule out synchronous bladder pathology, though less likely given ultrasound findings.
